title: Is Mobility Creep on the radar at all?
body:
I'm really worried that Riot has completely forgotten how valuable mobility is, especially with champions like Kalista and Yasuo who have dashes on virtually nonexistent cooldowns which cost nothing. 

The trouble is, given how powerful mobile champions are, Immobile champions tend to only be good if they're overpowered (Read: Syndra, Ryze) and otherwise there will basically *always* be a champion who does the same thing but with mobility.

Is this something that Riot has said anything about for the upcoming months?

You really don't understand how "creep" works, do you?

I'm gonna go to YGO for a perfect example of "power creep."

Season 1: Ace Monster-Dark Magician. Dark Magician is a "vanilla" monster with no effect, requiring two sacrifices to summon. He has 2500 atk, and 2100 def.

Zexal Season: Ace Monster-Utopia. Summonable on first turn with two level four monsters. He can cancel attacks twice before being destroyed (once for each detached material). 2500 atk, 2000 def.

That is power creep. From a late game powerhouse with a support structure to a first turn zerg rushable monster with an even larger support structure.

Clear?

Moving on to Mobility Creep:

By allowing an increase in the # or % of mobile champions, we increase movement creep because older champions are left behind, or, more accurately, because they are more mobile than the original champions were when released.
yup and riot makes old champs more mobile which removes mobility creep

You are kind of missing the point,

Mobility creep alludes to the fact that if Mobility becomes common for every champion, then there will be a subset of champions with weaker mobility that will need to be buffed. If riot then buffs their mobility, then another tier of champions will then have the weakest mobility and so on. It leads to the developers constantly buffing the mobility of the weakest champion until it becomes a power struggle in each patch. 

What league has right now is older champions with lower mobility, and newer champions with very high mobility. If we just continue to change each champion and introduce mobility into them, there will always be another set of champions that will then need to be buffed because their mobility doesn't cut it out anymore. It can work in some cases (ex. Dota has alot of power creep, where weaker champions get straight up buffed, as opposed to strong champions getting toned down) however, it leads to very stale gameplay and only a few champions being viable at the same time.
so basicaly nothing changes, then whats the problem ?

Putting it another way, mobility creep is the tendency for the game to have more and more mobility. It's achieved by making new champions with strong mobility and by giving mobility to those that "lack mobility". I think the biggest issue here is that we don't make mobile champions "pay" for mobility enough in their total power budget. Immobile mages are a good example of this fallout, as you mention.

When you have mobile champions that have the same or similar "raw" power output to a champion without mobility, it creates winners and losers really quickly. I agree here.

In this, I think mobile champions should be more tactically flexible (due to mobility) and have less raw power to compensate. I think, though, this will require more and nerfs and buffs. And will mostly be toning down the raw output of mobility champions (as you mentioned, Syndra and co are bullshit and remove gameplay decision-making due to power factors, so buffing immobile mages is not a good plan).

Preseason 2015 actually does help this in a strategy way in the meantime; jungle ganks, on average, are less frequent, giving less total pressure to immobile characters. This is some of what we saw with more traditional mage mids in Season 2 that we think will buff all these characters a little bit in the meantime.

That being said, I tend to think that (ADC) kits, on a very basic level, should not include these three elements together:

- High mobility
- Good AoE damage
- Long range on either abilities or autos.

At least not without having a very significant drawback.

For aforementioned AD carries, I mostly think four main champions have this trait of not having significant drawbacks:
{{champion:236}} : Spammable mobility via his dash, to the regard that his low AA range isn't a major factor. Strong waveclear with 3 AoE abilities, one that passes through minions one of which deals 400% damage to minions (although the last set of nerfs hit this strength a good deal). High range with 3 of 4 skills.
{{champion:51}} : Very long auto-attack range. Good, long ranged waveclear via pass-through Q. Mobility in her E. A long-ranged point&click damage tool (that can be blocked). Plus, unique secondary utility in persistent, snaring traps.
{{champion:42}} : Long-range, good damage poke in Q and R that doubles for waveclear. Q can't be blocked. High reposition mobility for escapes.
{{champion:18}} : Resetting jump for mobility. Gets to the highest persistent AA range in the game. E doubles as a good waveclear tool.

Comparing this to other high-mobility AD carries, who lack either one or more of these traits:
{{champion:81}} : Lacks non-ult waveclear unless building blue.
{{champion:67}} : No waveclear at all.
{{champion:15}} : Short auto-attack range, but unlike Lucian, no (spammable) instant repositioning tools. Boomerang Blade has long range, but isn't as good a fire-and-forget long ranged waveclear tool due to the harsh damage falloff. To devour waves, Sivir needs to get into AA range.
{{champion:133}} : Shorter than usual AA range. Low waveclear (Q doesn't do too much damage and doesn't pass through minions).

{{champion:222}} : Conditionally very mobile, very low mobility otherwise. Long range costs mana and has the drawback of low AS. Long-ranged single target skillshot telegraphed. Edge case, due to high utility (strong CC).

To see if I could put the argument to rest, I went ahead and analyzed 44 of League's first champions, and 44 of its most recent releases as well. My work is available at: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HAIeXQsD3_YQyVMo3sWNoE2Y1OfEelI9fv3h4ryNeYg/edit?usp=sharing

The earliest releases were Morgana through Gragas, in chronological order. **47% were mobile, 53% were not. 16% had situational mobility through their ultimates. **

The newest releases were Azir through Yorick, in reverse chronological order. **59% were mobile, 41% were not. 11% get their mobility through their ultimates.**

My litmus test for whether a champ is mobile was: *If ambushed, could this champ reliably escape? Could this champ reliably get on top of an opponent?*

Early League had the likes of Nidalee, Udyr, Shaco, Jax and Alistar.
Modern League has had the likes of Hecarim, Zed, Zac, and virtually all of the new releases.

On a year-by-year resolution, there does not appear to be a significant mobility creep; however new releases give the impression that mobility is definitely a defining factor on the new champion production-line.

It's also worth noting that *many* of the most mobile champions have become, or remained, quite situational picks with dubious win rates. It could be worth asking whether their kits are over nerfed to offset their mobility.

Okay here it is, my statistics for the same champions you listed: The oldest and the newest 44, observing mobility creep (https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1AkSyK_CP8NBpI95u_6XaMiHceKG0dZ-TjRXKubxtGBM/edit?usp=sharing).

**Of the original 44:**
 - 34.09% have MS buffs (I included Warwick, Nidalee and Malphite in this, despite each requiring specific targets/situations in which to use theirs);
 - 29.55% have dashes/blinks (I made a note of which are target abilities in the chart);
 - 22.73% have ults which grant them movement;
 - 2.78% (only 4 champions) have multiple mobility abilities;
 - A total of 34, 77.27%, have mobility abilities of some sort.

**Of the latest 44:**
 - 27.27% have MS buffs (Including Fiora, Viktor and Jinx, again despite the target/situational requirement);
 - 61.36% have dashes/blinks (including Diana, as her ult is on such a short CD);
 - 29.55% have movement ability ultimates (not including Diana in this number, see above);
 - 45.45% (20!) of these champions have multiple mobility abilities (Including Diana and Ahri's spammable multiple ult casts);
 - A total of 38, 86.36%, of the 44 newest champions have mobility abilities of some sort.

**NOTABLE TRENDS:**
 - Total champions with mobility abilities is up by 11.776%
 - Champions with MS buff abilities down by 20.00%
 - Champions with Dash/Blink abilities up by 107.69%
 - Multiple mobility abilities on champions up by 400.00% 
    ^ (This last stat is particularly damning. It used to be incredibly rare, now nearly 1 in 2 champions have multiple abilities to move around).

**TL;DR** MOBILITY CREEP IS CONFIRMED. Learn to interpret and collate data before acting smart.

I contend your definition of situational.

Of the ones you mentioned, Jax and Alistar require a target to use their leaps on, which is also situational, just not on a long CD like that of an (average) ultimate.

Hecarim, Zed, Zac, Jarvan, Riven of then new era all do not. I haven't statistically looked at every champ in those 40 brackets you specified, but I feel that if you do that, you will find your results becoming more significant. Feel free to prove me wrong on that gut feeling though if I am.

You also forgot the important distinction of ***BEING ABLE TO DODGE***. Anyone with only a self movement speed buff like Udyr, Malphite, and to a lesser extent champs like Rammus, Hecarim and Nidalee have considerably less ability to avoid damage and critically, CC, because they lack the quick position changing dash or blink of champs like Katarina, Yasuo, Elise, and all the afore mentioned, not to mention the ability to traverse walls without using flash...

My point is that there is a lot more factors to the determining of mobility creep than just those you have used as a basis for passing your 'mobile' requirement.

My problem with this situation is that Riot does often recognize it and point out that it's an issue and something that they're doing wrong... But then do nothing about it and release a champion with a kind of silly amount of mobility.  

Then they leave it alone a couple of months until someone brings it up again and they go "yeah it's still a problem" but it's just kind a loop that feeds onto it's self. Especially when the new champions get SO MUCH mobility now a days it feels like it's almost necessary on the kit... which is their own design flaw.

The solution is pretty tough and would require a lot of work but why doesn't Riot just like... Try? Trying would be cool. I like trying. :(

Also, please stop saying this is an issue at the same time while you're releasing a champ with INFINITE DASHES. It does sound like your left hand and right hand aren't even on the same page.

It's a problem, but the problem is the cost-benefit - not that "people can have lots of mobility." I think the right action on Kallista is make sure she's weaker at other things for having it, personally.

I mean, I think the issue everyone else in this thread is bringing up is that there's an acknowledgement of mobility creep pretty much every time someone brings it up, but nothing ever actually gets done about it. So we keep having this issue where there's very little reason to pick an immobile champion ever, because for 90% of immobile champions either

A. There exists another champion that does the same thing the immobile champion does while being mobile; for example, why would I ever pick Udyr (a high-damage jungler with 1 hard CC) when I could pick Vi (another high-damage jungler with mobility and a hard CC). 

B. They are screwed over so hard by enemy mobility that their advantages compared to the mobile champions are completely irrelevant. Take, for example, Ashe. She does something that no other mobile champion in the game does (ranged permaslow) but she's still not pickable because if the other team picks any kind of mobile assassin she's just going to feed them kill after kill. 

Let's take a look at some of the other members of the immobile champion roster for some more examples. 

{{champion:63}} : The immobility poster boy and IIRC the only champion to never be selected in any LCS game ever. Yeah, he will burst 2-3 people for 75% of their health in a teamfight. There is no reason to pick him over someone like Kennen (who bursts their entire team AND brings CC AND has mobility) or Xerath (who will also burst your team, but will do it from twice as far away as Brand). 

{{champion:3}} : He has an amazing ult and amazing utility overall in his kit. The problem is, unlike a Kennen or Wukong, he has no way to ever actually get in range to use his ult. There isn't really much reason to pick him when other champions have easier, more reliable engages. 

{{champion:222}}: She has every tool you could possibly want if you were trying to win bot lane while scaling into late game. But without mobility she simply can't do anything about someone like Zed or Yasuo. I know these characters are meant to be her counters but it still feels really stupid to win lane, get to mid/late game, go 100 range too close and get blown up before I can actually do anything in response. 

{{champion:77}} : Good luck trying to get in range to fight anyone ever. Udyr used to be one of the top guys for early damage because his Q procs were so strong. Every new champion who comes out with a gap closer weakened him, reducing the number of times where it was viable to pick him. Then Vi came out with obscene early damage of her own, decent jungle sustain, and actual gap closers, and there was no longer any reason to play Udyr. 

This is kind of a short list, and that's intentional. I didn't want to drag out this list too long because there are some immobile champions who are good ({{champion:61}}  because her kit is obscene, {{champion:96}} because he deals so much damage that it's worth protecting him, {{champion:53}} because he just brings you to him) but also because there are so many champions with other issues to deal with in the immobile champion pool and bringing them up just feels like a cheap shot ({{champion:41}} {{champion:82}} {{champion:6}} {{champion:83}}).

TL;DR actions speak louder then words

Riot is well aware of the mobility creep, but from what I've seen, their solution seems to be to give everyone mobility (for example, Soraka's passive gives you a lot of movement speed) or tools to deal with mobility (Soraka's E is pretty good for preventing dashes and also has a root), rather than removing mobility. I feel like they're increasing the skill ceiling on champions so the game is less about stats and more about strategic plays and mechanical strength (for example Sion, Sona, and Soraka reworks).
... Except Sona is not in any way mechanically demanding. In fact, she is mechanically one of the easiest to play in LoL's entire roster of champions.
...which is why they changed her so that her kit has some more strategic choices as far as her positioning, etc. compared to what she was before (a floating aura)

I think the best term for what riot is implementing is very gated mobility. Instead of having the power to instantly move from one place to another, all the time, in any direction (ezreal), they are creating champions that can access their mobility under certain circumstances. This is why we see older champions likes kassidin, and nidalee have much more toxic utility skills than newer champions like yasuo and kalista. Yes these champions can all out play you through dodging and closing the gap, or escape, but unlike the first 2, the latter is only able to when there is a target within a close range of themselves. 

As the game develops and older champions start getting changed, and healthier mobility (and non-mobility) kits are made from reworks, we will see a much more healthier league in terms of mobility. However, as of right now, it is true that champions with Dashes dominate certain categories like for ADC's and mid laners, however, we are starting to see exceptions there as well, aka, twitch, and xerath being very powerful meta champions.
